text: Just saw a LinkedIn Influencer with 'Organic Growth' written in the profile with 65K+ followers claiming that he can help you in growing your platform, copying the posts from other influencers.

Jobseekers, this one‚Äôs for you.
 Every application, every interview, every follow-up‚Ä¶ the pressure is immense.
 And I know what you're thinking: Am I not good enough? 
 But let me tell you, this isn‚Äôt about you or your skills. It‚Äôs about a broken system where 60% of applicants never hear back. 
 Your mental health is not worth sacrificing for a system that doesn‚Äôt acknowledge your worth. 
 Please remember, taking care of yourself is the real priority. 
 Your dream job will come, but for now, breathe. üåª
Looking for jobs on LinkedIn is like online dating: Full of promises, but in the end, you‚Äôre just left ghosted.

LinkedIn scams be like: 'Congratulations, you've been selected for a role you didn‚Äôt even apply for!' 
 The catch? Pay Rs. 50,000 for the honor.

sapne dekhna achi baat hai,
lekin job ka sapna dekh ke 'interested' likhna,
yeh toh achi baat nahi hai na?

Next time when I'll be reading some LinkedIn Influencer's story, I am starting from the last line.
If there's a link attached to it, it's most probably a fake one.
Saves me time!

Every time I poured my heart into 5-6 rounds of interviews and faced rejection, it felt like a punch in the gut. The sleepless nights, the endless preparation, all for nothing.

But looking back, I realize it wasn‚Äôt nothing. It was the Universe‚Äôs way of saying, ‚ÄúNot this one, something better is on the way.‚Äù

Every single time, I‚Äôve been shown why that rejection happened.

Doors I thought I wanted to walk through were shut, only to have the right ones swing open.

The kind that aligned with my growth, my values, and my happiness.

At first, it stung. It hurt deeply. But now, when things don‚Äôt go as planned, I don‚Äôt panic.

I don‚Äôt question my worth. I sit back, breathe, and trust. The Universe knows.

I know there's another plan waiting. Something bigger, better, and just for me.

To anyone feeling the weight of rejection: trust that the closed doors are protecting you from something you can‚Äôt see right now.

Your path is being cleared for something even more beautiful.

To everyone who's still looking for a job...

I see you. I feel you. 💔

Every rejection email feels like a punch in the gut, and every 'We'll get back to you' sounds more like 'You'll never hear from us.'

But I want you to know, you're not alone in this. 🌸

According to a study, 80% of jobseekers struggle with anxiety and self-doubt during their search. It's normal to feel lost, but it's not the end.

Take breaks, breathe, and remember, this doesn't define you. Your worth is not tied to an offer letter. 💥

Your mental health matters more than any job.

Sometimes, we forget that a company‚Äôs brand name doesn‚Äôt define someone‚Äôs talent. It‚Äôs easy to get caught up in the 'big company = big talent' mindset, but that's not always the case.

I‚Äôve had the privilege of working with people from smaller companies (lesser known) who blow me away with their skills and dedication. They don‚Äôt need a fancy title or a famous brand behind them to prove their worth.

I've seen the other side too‚Äîpeople in top-tier companies feeling lost, overwhelmed, or stuck, even though the world sees them as 'successful'.

Let‚Äôs stop attaching someone‚Äôs value to the company they work for. Freshers especially need to hear this‚Äîskills are what matter, not the size of the company behind them.

At the end of the day, happiness and growth don‚Äôt come from a brand name, they come from doing what you love and constantly improving your craft.

So when I left a toxic work environment, I told my manager a simple thing and felt so good 😯

I just said-

'Hope your son gets a manager like you.
I hope that the manager behaves the same way as you did with me.
Thank you.'

Now tell me 1 thing-

She always said that she was a great manager.
Why will she get offended?

I just told her that I wish her son would get a manager like she was.

If you felt bad, then that means you were a bad manager and now you know it. � 80

If you feel good, then take it as a blessing for your son and you'll really want someone to treat your son/daughter in the same way.

She cannot be even angry with me else it'll prove that she was not a 'great' manager.

Muskan - 1
Manager - 0

Muskan -> Aura +100000000

(Fictional message unfortunately :(
)

Hope you all become the people that your sons/daughters will like to work under 🙏

There are a lot of bad people/things, bring a small change and break the chain :)

SQL is a must-know topic for tech interviews, whether you're aiming for roles in software engineering, data analysis, or backend development. Almost every company tests SQL skills, so being prepared is key.

To make your preparation easier, I‚Äôve compiled a PDF guide with the most commonly asked SQL interview questions, covering:

Basic to Advanced SQL Queries
Joins, Subqueries and Indexing
Normalization and Denormalization
ACID Properties and Transactions
Stored Procedures, Triggers and More

Let‚Äôs make SQL easy and ace that interview.

- We have some amazing guidance videos on my YouTube channel

- We have CSES video solutions in the pipeline for you to solve topic-wise problems. Already posted solutions for 4 sections
- We have a contest tracker on TLE‚Äôs website so that you never miss a contest
- We post video solutions after every contest on Codeforces, LeetCode, CodeChef and AtCoder to help you upsolve
- We have an amazing beginner-friendly blog series lined up on our newly launched CP-Digest, to help you keep track of major events and get guidance and insights from experienced competitive programmers

There is a lot more free content coming from TLE Eliminators in 2026. Below is an image of me preparing some of it.

One thing I see often in interviews. Big red flag:

When you show up for a job interview, whether you‚Äôre a fresher or a C-level leader, please don‚Äôt start with "what the company should do."

An interview is not a consulting session.

It‚Äôs a conversation. And curiosity always beats advice.

Red flags I notice instantly:

1. Not really listening
2. Jumping into advice mode
3. Thinking about the answer before the question is even finished
4. No curiosity about the business, people, or context
5. Answering everything too fast. If you never pause and think even once, you sound like a bot

Green flags that stand out:

1. Be a great listener
2. Set the agenda and respect time
3. Keep it conversational, like you‚Äôre talking to another human
4. Sell yourself without trying to sell
5. Ask thoughtful questions. That only happens when you‚Äôve actually read and understood the company

Strong interviews aren‚Äôt about sounding smart. They‚Äôre about showing judgment, curiosity, and self-awareness.

Today‚Äôs hiring harsh reality:

Interview ‚úîÔ∏è
Technical round ‚úîÔ∏è
Salary discussion ‚úîÔ∏è

And then‚Ä¶ Disappear

No update.
No feedback.
No rejection.
Just silence.

Candidates invest time, money, effort, and hope.
The bare minimum they deserve?

One clear response ‚Äî even a "No."

Ghosting after interviews isn‚Äôt normal.
It‚Äôs not because of busy schedules.
It‚Äôs poor professionalism.

Feedback costs nothing.
Silence costs trust, reputation, and employer brand.

Let‚Äôs normalize closure over silence.

#hiring #corporatelife

What Google Interviews Taught Me!

Behind every "Offer Accepted" post you see on your feed, there are often dozens of emails just like this one in the archive. It‚Äôs easy to post offer letters. It‚Äôs much harder to post the "No" but a "No" often teaches you more than a "Yes" ever could.

I gave three rounds for the University Grad (2026 Batch) role at Google. I didn‚Äôt get the offer. I remember staring at the email: "Not moving forward." Honestly, it stung. I questioned my preparation. I questioned my skills.

But looking back, I realize I walked away with lessons that changed how I approach engineering.

Here are a few key lessons I took from my Google interview experience:

1. In Round 1, I saw a familiar Binary Tree problem similar to a LeetCode Hard I had solved before. But the interviewer added a variation that made it significantly tougher. If I had simply memorized the code, I would have failed instantly. Because I understood the core concept, I was able to solve the variation.

The lesson: Never memorize solutions. Memorization will not help you pass interviews. When you practice, do not just solve problems, try to solve variations. That is where real confidence comes from.

2. "Vocal Debugging" sounded new to me until my interview. During Round 3, I was not allowed to write code or even use a pen for the first 15 minutes. I had to run a complex greedy algorithm entirely in my head and predict the output array.

The lesson: We practice on screens and paper, but we rarely practice mental compilation. Try doing dry runs in your head. It forces you to visualize data flow and builds raw logical strength.

3. I faced situational questions around teamwork and ownership in both Round 2 and Round 3. Many candidates either try to memorize answers or ignore this part completely. I realized you should not script answers, but you must have a framework. Under pressure, it is very hard to structure a clear story if you have not organized your thoughts beforehand.

The lesson: You can be a great coder, but if you cannot communicate your thought process or explain how you handle failure, you will not clear the bar. In big tech, soft skills are hard skills.

Hope this adds some value to your journey.

For the full technical breakdown of the questions and rounds, check my previous post here: https://lnkd.in/gguehKN9

Top Google DSA Interview Questions

Cracking a Google interview requires strong problem-solving skills, clean logic, and optimized solutions.

These Top Google DSA Interview Questions are curated from real Google interview patterns, focusing on data structures, algorithms, and edge-case handling that Google interviewers deeply evaluate.

Perfect for developers preparing for:
- Google
- Product-based companies
- High-level DSA interviews

Topics Covered (Google Focus):
- Arrays and Strings (Sliding Window, Two Pointers)
- Hashing and Prefix Sum
- Recursion and Backtracking
- Binary Trees and BST
- Graphs (BFS, DFS, Shortest Path)
- Dynamic Programming
- Greedy Algorithms
- Bit Manipulation
- Time and Space Complexity

Why Google DSA Questions Matter:
- Emphasis on optimized solutions
- Clear explanation of thought process
- Strong edge-case analysis
- Real-world problems
